newsitem.title: UK: Courtaulds, MSAS in cargo computer tie-up.
newsitem.headline: Courtaulds, MSAS in cargo computer tie-up.

text.p: Britain's Courtaulds Plc and MSAS Cargo International said they have jointly developed a computerised stock order management and processing system.
Called 'Insight', they said in a statement it is a PC-based software application that replaces manual processes and controls in manufacturing and shipping.

MSAS information technology director Leigh Stone, who designed the software, said that 'Insight' linked MSAS and Courtaulds offices in the UK with their respective offices and factory near Colombo, Sri Lanka, where garments bound for the UK market are manufactured.
"The communication of manufacture, shipment, delivery orders and invoices is transmitted via EDI messages," he said.

The majority of shipments go by sea with a lead time of three weeks. But airfreight is used when new stock is urgently required by retailers or to maintain the flow of goods if production drops behind schedule, the statement said.

It added that data used to track and trace all consignments by style, colour and size from factory gate through to loading, shipping, arrival in the UK, customs clearance and delivery to door is captured from MSAS's Unitel 21 system and fed by EDI message into Insight.

"This new system has helped us to eliminate wastage and human error, and improved productivity by moving away from the transmission of information by paper over to a computerised system that is easy to access for all those in Sri Lanka and the UK", said Steve Herbert, manager of distribution for Courtaulds Clothing International.
